section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children in movement, and introduce vocabulary (shelter, real).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How can we help pets stay healthy?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share observations about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn.
Understand what it means to be a consumer.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to classify animals as “real” or “not real.”
Guide children to talk about why each animal shown is real or not real.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What pet do you see in your book? How would you care for it?
Pretend you have a cat that needs attention. Show how you would show love and attention to your pet?
What food would you give to a pet? What food would you eat yourself? Sort the food.
Draw a picture of your favorite pet. What is its name?
Can you make a colorful bowl for your pet?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word pet? Can you write the letter?
Can you use blocks build a safe place for a small pet to play?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder express pride and introduce vocabulary (proud, care for).
Begin Story Time by connecting the expressing pride Mind Builder to Lola Gets a Cat.
Read closely talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share observations about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Understand and use a growing number of common phrases; Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions.
Exercise good habits of personal safety.
Understand what it means to be a consumer.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children talk about pictures of children who are proud of something they have done.
Guide children to talk about how people show pride and what they themselves might be proud of.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show an animal that is being cared for? How is it being taken care of?
Show me how you walk when you feel proud of yourself.
Can you build something that you are proud of? What makes it special?
When have you felt proud? Can you write about it?
Can you build something a pet could play with? What kind of toy will you make?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word care? Can you show me?
Show how you could use blocks to build a tall tower.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Lola Gets a Cat by Anna McQuinn, illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. Text copyright © 2017 by Anna McQuinn. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Rosalind Beardshaw. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Comprehension skill Ask and Answer Questions and introduce vocabulary (pretends, evening).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Lola Gets a Cat and asking the guiding question, What does Lola’s new pet Makeda need?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share observations about stories; Tell or retell stories.
Understand and use personal and possessive pronouns; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Understand what it means to be a consumer.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children talk about pictures that show children with their pets.
Guide children to use possessive pronouns as they talk about the children and their pets.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you show a book with an animal? Can this animal be a pet? What do you think it needs?
Pretend you are going to walk your dog. What would you need to do first?
How can you use counters to show each pet that you know?
What would you do to care for a new pet? Can you write about it?
Make a picture of the things you might have to buy for a new pet.
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words evening and eat? Can you show me?
How would you build a cozy home for a pet? What will it have?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Lola Gets a Cat by Anna McQuinn, illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. Text copyright © 2017 by Anna McQuinn. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Rosalind Beardshaw. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: What Pets Need

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what pets need and to introduce vocabulary words (exercise, pets).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts What Pets Need and Lola Gets a Cat.
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question, “What do animals need to stay healthy?”
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of text read aloud; Compare and contrast information from a text.
Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Recognize good habits of nutrition and exercise.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Social Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children talk about pictures of animals that are pets and animals that are wild.
Guide children to talk about differences between animals that can live in your home and animals that do not.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Show me an animal that is a pet. What do you think makes it a good pet?
Compare wolves to pet dogs. How are they the same? How are they different? Can you pretend to be a pet dog and then a wolf?
What do wild animals need to stay healthy? What are some ways you can help them? For instance, can you fill a bird bath with water for wild birds? What are some other ways?
Think about what a pet needs. What could you write about it?
Can you draw a picture of two pets you would like to play with?
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning sound you hear in pets and puppies?
How could you build a special place for your pet to play? What do you think your pet would like?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Lola Gets a Cat by Anna McQuinn, illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. Text copyright © 2017 by Anna McQuinn. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Rosalind Beardshaw. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children act out what people need to do for their pets and what pets do in return, and introduce vocabulary (favorite, fresh).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Lola Gets a Cat and asking the guiding question, If you were a cat, what would you need to stay healthy?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Tell or retell stories.

Respond to instructional language; Understand and use a growing number of personal and possessive pronouns; Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and activities.
Show self-awareness in multiple ways.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: If you were a pet, what would you want most?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we help animals stay healthy?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book about what a cat needs, what would you put in it?
Pretend you are going to go out to buy supplies for a new pet. What will you need to buy?
How many counters do you think you would use to measure a cat?
Imagine being a cat that moves to a new home. Write a story as if you are the cat.
Imagine what the fluffiest cat in the world looks like. Can you draw a picture?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the words fresh and favorite?
Can you create a model of a cat? What materials will you use?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Lola Gets a Cat by Anna McQuinn, illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. Text copyright © 2017 by Anna McQuinn. Illustrations copyright © 2017 by Rosalind Beardshaw. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Classify and organize to group and arrange items.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions.
Practice good habits of personal safety.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom

Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Demonstrate understanding of what it means to be a consumer.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Identify good habits of nutrition and exercise.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age appropriate abilities and skills.
Use imagination to think about or picture something.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
